30.02.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up,
how do you keep your police force happy? Where

36.23.text:
do you site your gun cabinet? Big calibres
after big game. We are after red hartebeest

42.39.text:
in Namibia. But first the other end of the
scale. We are looking at accurate air gunning

47.80.text:
with our legend in his own underpants, Roy
Lupton.

53.77.text:
Most people are introduced to shooting through
air rifles. Many are then eager to step up

58.17.text:
onto proper rifles - but there is a lot to
be said for endeavouring to master the art

62.66.text: of one before moving onto a bigger bang.

66.49.text:
Roy has always been an airgun fan but for
a bit of an experiment and more importantly

72.23.text:
to improve his accuracy we are going to do
some back of envelope calculations - well

79.95.text:
As I have not used an air rifle for quite
some time, we thought it would be a good idea

83.99.text:
to just come out and have a bit of play on
the target. So we are going to put a series

87.53.text:
of dots on here and just figure out where
we are shooting at different ranges. Because

92.17.text:
obviously with a sub 12ftlb air rifle then
the tragectory can be quite steep. .35 and

99.09.text:
then we shall do one at .50. So we will just
see where our ranges are and exactly where

106.76.text:
the gun is shooting before we go out and use
it in anger.

110.58.text:
Roy has zeroed in at 25 yards but will start
at 10 and work backwards.

115.88.text:
A range finder is a vital bit of kit for this
sort of work. It is essential if we want to

121.15.text:
find out just what happens to our pellets
as they battle against gravity and the forces

127.08.text:
You are obviously trying to shoot head shots
on a lot of animals. So you have a very small

131.35.text:
target area. So what you are trying to do
is to make sure you can be as precise as possible.

134.99.text:
So having a range finder really does enable
you just with pin point accuracy to figure

139.82.text:
out where you are and with the mil dots in
the scope if you know where you are on the

143.59.text:
range then you can easily adjust up or down
just with a little bit of hold over or hold

147.95.text: under and you should be smack on the target.

150.18.text:
And we will send the pellet on the way, like
that. So actually at .10 that is not too low

156.63.text:
at all. So we will just put another one in
just to make sure, and same hole. That is

167.29.text:
exactly what we should expect from an air
rifle of this sort of quality. So it is the

172.72.text:
same hole grouping. So we will move back to
.25 and see where we go.

178.39.text:
Right, ok so we are smack on 25, all focused
in. We shall just put one up the chamber,

184.94.text:
almost same position. So we will do it again.
And we are there again. So actually it is

199.27.text: just a touch over to the left.

202.30.text:
At 35 yards things start to get a bit more
tricky and Roy has to compensate for drop

206.38.text:
off with hold over and there is the gusting
wind.

210.34.text:
So we are on .35 yards here and I am just
going to hit the recall button and I would

216.20.text:
have expected that we will get may be a mil
dot drop on here, but we shall soon found

221.92.text:
out. Hit that on the target. There you go.
Actually mil dot and a half and yet we are

228.05.text:
slightly to the left on here shooting through.
So we will put another one down. See if we

232.94.text:
get the same result. Down there like that,
so yes the wind is interfering. So that one

242.39.text:
is a little bit further down as well. So we
have just got to take into consideration that

249.30.text:
we have a bit of side wind. So what we would
do now at .35 yards is if we were aiming straight

255.49.text:
at that target with no wind, we would put
that mil dot straight on it at .35 yards and

260.55.text:
we then we should be straight onto it. But
we have also got a little bit of windage as

264.97.text:
well. So with the windage what we are going
to do is come across, a mil dot across like

270.89.text:
that. So we are going to aim off the target
like so and we will just see whether we can

274.87.text: get anywhere near the target there.

279.48.text:
So what you saw on the shot there was a perfect
height. We had adjusted up, so we were absolutely

286.27.text:
spot on on line of where we wanted to be,
but obviously with the different wind strength

292.12.text:
it is going to always going to affect the
pellet depending if you hit or shoot in a

295.87.text:
gust or a lull in the wind. So that is what
you have always got to try and do. If you

300.00.text:
are having to go out and are shooting in the
wind always be aware of it especially with

303.26.text: an air rifle. And then just make your compensations.

307.21.text:
At fifty the shot has dropped about 6 inches
- but a couple of shots with adjustment puts

314.17.text:
You can see we have a huge drop off on .50
being zeroed at .25. So then we adjusted for

322.46.text:
it so we know where we need to be on that.
We came up here and then just adjusted for

326.95.text:
the windage and the height from that shot
to there so we knew where we were. Another

332.36.text:
final adjustment and we were smack on at the
.50 yards. So hopefully we know pretty much

337.05.text: where we are going to be.

339.45.text:
So with a clear picture of where that pellet
is flying it is time for an airgun safari.

345.25.text:
Roy's eccentric family home has a wide range
of bird life from eagles to doves to peacocks

351.15.text:
- so there is plenty of food about for crows,
pigeons, rabbits and squirrels.

357.44.text:
With the camera watching Roy's every move
we can analyse where he's putting the cross

361.57.text: hairs and see just how the quarry reacts.

363.68.text:
OK so we have got a carrion crow which has
just landed in the tree there. I reckon he

380.30.text:
Oh, no way. That just parted his feathers
by the looks of that. I just want to look

391.69.text:
at that on replay. I think I just undercompensated
where he was sitting high up in the tree there.

400.50.text:
The shot looked like it just went straight
over the top of his head and skimmed it. And

405.76.text:
I think that must be down to the angle that
I was shooting at. I was aiming smack on,

409.99.text:
but the pellet went above. So I think I didn't
compensate because we were shooting at quite

414.47.text:
a steep angle up. Oh well, hopefully another
one will come in.

421.79.text:
OK so about 40 yards. Ooh excellent. I want
to have a look at that. He was just on about

441.42.text:
45 yards. And you can see that look. And it
just drops. I didn't quite allow enough but

448.00.text:
with the angle of where the drop off was coming
it was directly in line of where his neck

452.85.text:
was. So luckily it took him out there. So
that was a nice clean kill. So he was done.

458.45.text:
Right let's see if we can get a couple more.
We have got a feral pigeon sitting up here.

464.47.text:
We will see if we can put a few ferals in
the bag. Keep the ferrets going for a few

469.30.text:
days. See if we can get him. He is about 20
yards. So that should be aiming smack on.

476.31.text:
Ok just wait for his head to come round. And,
yes, ok, perfect, excellent. Right any more.

492.74.text: No nothing there at the moment.

497.11.text:
The reason we are shooting the ferals is that
we have quite a big population of white doves

500.05.text:
here and with the white doves obviously they
attract in a lot of other pigeons. When they

505.38.text:
come in they can bring disease and whatever
else in so we are constantly trimming the

510.07.text:
feral pigeons and what have you as they come
in. And we also trim up the white doves as

513.67.text:
well, because we end up with a flock of about
2 or 300 come the winter otherwise. It is

518.63.text:
always a good source of food for the ferrets
and what ever else through the season. So

523.48.text:
when we get the opportunity to pop a few off,
we certainly take it.

527.25.text:
This is a shot we had a bit earlier and it
was a miss on a rabbit. I just want to see

531.63.text:
exactly what happened. I am presuming I must
have hit over the top. So that is the wonderful

537.77.text:
thing with this camera. It shows you your
mistakes and where you went wrong. Hopefully

542.90.text:
we can see the muzzle go in a second. Wow
look at that. That is phenomenal. You actually

549.42.text:
see the pellet arcing just over the top of
his head and him ducking down. I don't know

555.77.text:
whether he saw that coming or just felt it.
I think he just felt it as it went over his

561.97.text:
head. Again that really just hightlights how
effective you have got to be on your range

566.23.text:
finding. You have got to really either take
a range finder out with you, or be as good

571.29.text:
or as accurate as you can in getting your
ranges. It is probably worth going out and

574.98.text:
trying beforehand, because that rabbit was,
I think, 35 yards and I had allowed for a

583.50.text:
40 yard shot. So I just aimed a little bit
too far above his ears. This was a rabbit

590.23.text:
shot by a young friend of mine Jordan and
it really does

595.33.text:
demonstrate how bad the windage can be or
your windage adjustment needs to be, as we

600.29.text:
showed when shooting at the target. So when
the pellet goes, you can see it was taken

605.78.text:
by the wind. So on this shot we have got a
left to right wind. You can see it taking

612.36.text:
the pellet right over and rather than hitting
in the head of the rabbit it goes in and hits

618.02.text:
it square in the chest. Still a very clean
kill shot, but not the one he was after. So

623.23.text:
you can see that he had already come forward.
He had come forward to allow for the windage,

627.55.text:
but just not quite enough. Luckily the pellet
still found its mark.

631.62.text:
We've had some success but Roy is not overly
happy. He thinks that some fine tuning could

637.42.text:
improve his accuracy. One of the problems
has been changing the magnification on the

642.21.text:
scope - this has been putting the mil dots
out, which means the adjustments he has making

649.56.text:
He also wants to re zero at 35 yards and work
through the ranges again. He believes this

655.09.text:
will deliver a flatter trajectory, which means
less time worrying about compensating for

662.55.text:
That is about right, level wise we are just
a touch off , but that is ok. Ok and spot

669.49.text:
on. So we are now at 20 yards. Just make sure
we are on. See where it is going at .20 give

678.70.text:
us some sort of idea. Just to make sure, always
take a couple of shots. That one is exactly,

688.58.text:
one mil dot high there. On to the .40, again
the wind is taking a little bit there. On

698.96.text:
to the .50, it seems to be more in line, but
the wind stops there, we didn't get any windage

710.43.text:
issues. This is out to .60 and we will see
how much more drop away we get with just that

721.67.text:
So let's now look at the complete picture
for four different scenarios.

726.61.text:
.22 zeroed at 25 yards there and we have got
a huge curve off and drop off like that. So

737.84.text:
from the very start all the way through we
were just trying to catch our tails all the

741.49.text:
time. The pellet from the moment it was leaving
the barrel was curving away from us. With

746.00.text:
a .22 zeroed at 35 yards, excuse my writing
it is awful. You can see here we started off

754.46.text:
at 10 a little bit high at 10, then we have
got the curve going up, over, round, dropping

759.68.text:
off and then really dropping away there. This
is .22 zeroed at 30 yards. Slightly low at

768.49.text:
10, but not enough off to really matter then
we just go up a bit to 20, through 30 perfectly,

775.93.text:
and drop down to 50. So that is almost a more
useable curve of the trajectory on there.

782.19.text:
And then just to show the differences. What
we have got here we shot the same targets,

787.27.text:
the same ranges with a .177. So we have got
a .177 that was zeroed at 40 yards. So you

797.77.text:
can see spot on at 10, little bit high at
20, still rising at 30, smack on at 40, down

805.13.text:
through to 50. It was dropping off there.
But

809.93.text:
throughout the range of 10 to 40 a much better
trajectory.

814.46.text:
Interesting stuff and with this is mind Roy
chooses to zero at 30 and head off after some

820.02.text:
more bunnies - The first is at 30 yards so
in theory should be spot on. Even though it

826.57.text:
takes some grass seeds with it, the pellet
finds its target, exactly where the cross

833.10.text:
The second rabbit Roy has since described
as a "ninja" - This shot is at 17 yards - again

840.26.text:
remembering we are zeroed at 30 Roy puts the
cross hairs level with the eye. He expects

845.64.text:
the pellet to be rising so will find the target
between centre and the first mil dot. However,

851.75.text:
this rabbits has other ideas and ducks - not
in response to a low flying object soaring

857.59.text:
over his head but just before the pellet reaches
its target. Slowing the shot down further

863.64.text:
it clearly shows the ear being clipped - did
it hear the shot? - did it see the pellet?

869.48.text:
- you tell us - whatever you think it is a
great excuse if you miss!!!!

876.23.text:
Lots of our air gunning videos if you look
at the screen which is appearing over my left

880.78.text:
Now it is off to David on the Fieldsports
Channel News Stump.

894.67.text:
The first 100lb-plus carp has been caught
by an Austrian angler in Hungary. Roman Hanke

902.63.text:
caught the mirror carp earlier this month
at the Euro-Aqua Fishery, which costs 700

907.21.text:
euros a week to fish. ThePrevious record was
jointly held by Brits, Ambrose Smith and John

913.46.text:
Bryan with a 99lb fish from Le Graviers Fishery
in Dijon, France. The new record fell for

922.70.text:
The Countryside Alliance has published 'the
case for hunting'. Four years ago it produced

927.98.text:
the ĹCase for Repeal' but, has not until
now produced a single concise document on

932.95.text:
the positives for hunting. It has now filled
the gap. Download it from www.countryside-alliance.org

940.95.text:
Pacific Bluefin tuna caught off the Californian
coast have been found to have radioactive

945.74.text:
traces from last year's Fukushima nuclear
accident. The bluefin tuna breeds and spends

952.36.text:
its first couple of years off Japan before
swimming to the Claifornia coast. Yellowfin

956.91.text:
tuna, which tend to stay put around the Californian
coast, are not radioactive. Scientists say

962.33.text:
there is no danger from eating Californian
bluefin.

965.50.text:
Once upon a time there were eagles soaring
all over the English countryside. New research

971.60.text:
in the journal Bird Study uses place names
to show the distribution of both golden and

976.60.text:
sea eagles during the Dark Ages.Village names
beginning An or Arn mean 'eagle' so they believe

984.00.text:
places such as Adlington, Arden where home
to these great birds. Of course an RSPB spokeswoman

990.07.text:
quickly blamed gamekeepers for the birds'
decline.

993.80.text:
Clips from the Jeremy Wade series about big
game fishing are now on YouTube. Visit the

998.97.text:
AnimalPlanetTV channel to see films such as
this one, about shark fishing for the requiem

1005.51.text:
And finally a nasty story about a rogue kangaroo
who stalked a woman for two days before attacking

1012.11.text:
her. Australian housewife Kirrily McWilliams
was confronted in her own back yard by a growling

1017.39.text:
female eastern grey kangaroo. The usually
placid animal attacked her in her driveway

1022.59.text:
the following afternoon. It ran towards her
at high speed. She sustained a foot-long gash

1027.97.text:
and other scratches. The local wildlife service
has hired a shooter and issued a permit to

1035.29.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

1045.22.text:
Now where do you site your gun cabinet? We
asked the experts at Browning.

1050.83.text:
Andy Norris is looking for a good place to
site his new gun cabinet.

1054.93.text:
So we need to find somewhere we can place
our cabinet that is going to be out of sight,

1058.81.text:
out of mind and safe as houses. We can't keep
it outside on an external wall where it is

1064.42.text:
going to be visible and easy to access. We
don't want to keep it in an outbuilding that

1069.37.text:
is also going to be easy to get into, like
a barn. So we need to keep it indoors where

1074.07.text:
it is also warm and we can keep an eye on
it and it is looked after by your household

1081.78.text:
security. You can't put it on a stud wall
because you can get something behind it, gem

1083.76.text:
it off and you have got nothing to fix it
to. So what we are looking for here Nevil

1090.32.text:
is a solid indoor internal wall that we can
fix this cabinet to, so that the raw bolts

1096.61.text:
are really going to be able to do their duty
and lock in there nice and solid and not easy

1102.03.text:
Well that is jolly clear. Clever Andy Norris
- or should that be clever Browning. Visit

1107.38.text:
Next, let's take those guns out of the gun
cabinet and take them big game hunting in

1129.21.text:
What kind of African hunting lodge does not
have a show-off collection of mounts? There

1135.06.text:
can be good ones and bad ones. This giraffe
is quite special. It is in the Blaser Safaris

1140.53.text:
catalogue and Blaser is often contacted by
people asking for more details about how it

1146.88.text:
Of course it takes a lot of hard work to get
to this from this. We want to go out with

1152.29.text:
Spanish hunter Alejandro as he looks for a
red hartebeest, one of the largest antelope

1157.46.text:
in Namibia. First he has to get to grips with
big game calibres on the range, ammunitions

1163.22.text:
supplied by Norma, rifles by Blaser, optics
by Zeiss.

1168.28.text:
Stefan Buehring from Karl Zeiss is Alejandro's
host in Namibia and he explains what the hunter

1174.66.text:
In this specific scope we have a very unique,
new lense design. Which was developed by our

1182.94.text:
sister company Schott and which just gives
us an extra percentage up to 95% of light

1191.74.text:
transmission. So that is especially for the
very early morning hours or for the late evening

1197.65.text:
hours that gives you another 5% compared to
other scopes.

1202.22.text:
As usual with big game hunting, nothing happens
easily. But then at last it all starts to

1209.14.text:
Was the shot good? Alejandro is not sure.
He walks up to where he hopes he will find

1214.67.text: the animal and there it is.

1216.99.text:
The situation was that I was close behind
the guide when he asked me to come forward.

1219.67.text:
He positioned the shooting stick and asked
me to aim. But when I was aiming from the

1223.24.text:
shooting stick I was only able to shoot in
one position. I knew that I would get just

1228.53.text:
one opportunity to shoot - so I shot. I knew
that if I didn't shoot within those two seconds,

1233.10.text: the animal would probably have moved and disappeared.

1235.23.text:
Aleandro's wife and fellow hunter Patricia
is soon on the scene and they have an emotional

1239.96.text:
reunion. Jorgen is also happy, but mainly
about the performance of his ammunition.

1245.32.text:
The design behind the Norex bullet is that
it is bonded which means it will retain a

1249.72.text:
lot of weight and it will also penetrate very
deep and crush bone and also the bonding makes

1258.29.text:
it very strong so it doesn't disintegrate
when it goes through. Especially on heavier

1264.82.text:
game like African large antelopes and moose.
It is important that you have a bullet that

1272.45.text:
really penetrates deep enough to reach the
vital organs. Like the heart and the lungs.

1278.69.text:
The process is not over. The carcase has to
come back to the lodge to be skinned and butchered.

1284.17.text:
This gives Jorgen a chance to look for the
bullet.

1287.47.text:
It has mushroomed to a very large mushroom
and it has penetrated right through the animal

1292.98.text: and we found it on the skin side.

1295.34.text:
How much of the bullet is left inside the
animal?

1298.25.text:
Very little. Since this bullet is bonded most
of the lead and all of the jacket is bonded

1307.71.text:
together and this means we have a very high
weight retention.

1312.43.text:
Now we are heading for that heady moment when
Alejandro will be able to admire the head

1317.16.text:
on his wall. Here in the cutting room the
meat goes one way and the hide or head, or

1321.93.text:
both go the other, into the salting room for
drying.

1324.98.text:
He has had a good hunt. He has had a hard
hunt. He has got his trophy. Now comes one

1330.46.text:
of the most important parts of this whole
process is dealing with this animal. It comes

1336.39.text:
into the skinning shed. It gets off loaded
as soon as possible. It gets, depending on

1343.82.text:
what the client wants, it gets cut up into
a flat skin or a cape or whatever the case

1350.89.text:
may be. The skinners and the trackers do the
skinning. The heads are cleaned off and the

1357.92.text:
skins are brought here. They get put into
salt. They get spread out layer of salt at

1363.68.text:
the bottom. They get salted very well for
a couple of days.

1369.85.text:
That ensures that there is no decomposition,
or minimises decomposition and kills the bugs.

1379.01.text:
Trophies are not super-fashionable in the
UK these days but they are a fantastic way

1386.55.text:
That is what he takes back with him. The memories.
Years after he has come to Namibia and hunted

1395.71.text:
this animal and he has got this trophy up
on the wall. That is actually what he retains

1407.11.text:
Call them a souvenir if you like, they are
long way up the scale from a straw hat or

1411.55.text:
wooden giraffe. This red hartebeest mount
will take pride of place as a mount in Alejandro's

1420.03.text:
So that is what we have been doing. Let's
have a look at the rest of what the hunting

1423.53.text:
and shooting and fishing community on YouTube
has been up to.

1428.58.text:
Roebuck, Coke cans, rats, rabbits, pretend
wild boar and a new use for an old oil filter.

1434.82.text:
They're all on Hunting YouTube this week,
which aims to show the best hunting, shooting

1439.08.text:
and fishing videos that YouTube has to offer.
Thanks to everyone who has sent in their favourite

1445.00.text:
YorkshireRoeStalking continues his epic series
on bucks that can no longer be seen in Yorkshire.

1449.96.text:
This one, called Trevor's first outing, shows
a buck succumbing to a 6.5x55.

1455.17.text:
Viewer Tristan Ball says of this video: "It
is, I'm afraid, all in French and some of

1458.97.text:
the shots are a bit crap but it's quite fun.
Uploaded by Seladang, it shows kids going

1462.73.text:
roebuck stalking in France. Some of the shots
are a bit dodgy, that terrier is clearly untrained

1468.31.text:
(and I should know) and stone me if they don't
celebrate a successful shot by kissing each

1472.28.text:
other in most unBritish fashion but Tristan
is right, "it's quite fun".

1477.04.text:
Coming from a world where there is no such
thing as an ordinary roebuck, TeamWildHunting

1481.20.text:
is after monster roebucks in Hungary. The
hunt is, as usual, 'awesome'. When is it not?

1486.70.text:
A couple of weeks ago we showed you a film
about YouTube gamers putting down their pretend

1490.79.text:
AK47s and picking up proper Brownings to try
out clay pigeon shooting. We explained how

1496.03.text:
they were becoming famous on YouTube for showing
film from video games such as Modern Warfare

1500.48.text:
while talking about their girlfriends and
their exams. Well now there's a spotty Continental

1505.28.text:
lad called FlabbergastingMe doing the same
over footage from a video game called The

1510.12.text: Hunter. Dear me - it's just not healthy.

1512.45.text:
In this film, ASA37MM and his mate Tom test
the Econo Can on pistols, rifles, and full

1519.03.text:
autos. What is the Econo Can? It's one of
those mad ideas that land on the gun trade

1523.22.text:
from time to time: a threaded attachment that
allows you to improvise a moderator out of

1527.33.text:
a car's oil filter. Oh yes. The thing is,
as this video shows, it really works. Neil

1532.70.text:
Hawkins, who sent in the video, says "I'm
not sure my local Firearms Liaison Officer

1537.82.text:
Lots of people hated our Test Splat Special
series but a handful of you clearly loved

1542.67.text:
it. Here is a tribute act by Jimbarbwe1985
showing in fabulous slow-mo a CZ .22 rimfire

1549.11.text:
thumbhole laminated stock with moderator plus
Winchester Super X .22LR 40GR subsonic hollowpoint

1555.73.text:
ammunition shooting lemonade, coke, tomato,

days more than the mellifluous Northern Irish

1570.76.text:
tones of HuntersVermin? In this film, rabbit

1575.66.text:
as he messes up a long range shot and is lucky

1580.71.text:
Diggers and dogs. That's how to go ratting

1586.21.text:
shows. It has had a quarter of a million views

1601.32.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1604.55.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1612.11.text:
If you enjoyed our show this week you might
enjoy the Shooting Show. You will see a clip

1615.73.text:
of it in the sky above my left shoulder just
there. Or you can subscribe to us on YouTube

1621.67.text:
or go to our shows page which is www.youtube.com/show/fieldsportsbritain

1643.99.text: you. This has been Fieldsports Britain.
